member.name: T:Amazon.Kafka.Model.BrokerNodeGroupInfo
member.summary: Describes the setup to be used for Kafka broker nodes in the cluster.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.BrokerNodeGroupInfo.BrokerAZDistribution
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BrokerAZDistribution.
The distribution of broker nodes across Availability Zones. This is an optional parameter. If you don't specify it, Amazon MSK gives it the value DEFAULT. You can also explicitly set this parameter to the value DEFAULT. No other values are currently allowed.
Amazon MSK distributes the broker nodes evenly across the Availability Zones that correspond to the subnets you provide when you create the cluster.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.BrokerNodeGroupInfo.ClientSubnets
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ClientSubnets.
The list of subnets to connect to in the client virtual private cloud (VPC). AWS creates elastic network interfaces inside these subnets. Client applications use elastic network interfaces to produce and consume data. Client subnets can't be in Availability Zone us-east-1e.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.BrokerNodeGroupInfo.InstanceType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstanceType.
The type of Amazon EC2 instances to use for Kafka brokers. The following instance types are allowed: kafka.m5.large, kafka.m5.xlarge, kafka.m5.2xlarge,kafka.m5.4xlarge, kafka.m5.12xlarge, and kafka.m5.24xlarge.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.BrokerNodeGroupInfo.SecurityGroups
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SecurityGroups.
The AWS security groups to associate with the elastic network interfaces in order to specify who can connect to and communicate with the Amazon MSK cluster. If you don't specify a security group, Amazon MSK uses the default security group associated with the VPC.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.BrokerNodeGroupInfo.StorageInfo
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StorageInfo.
Contains information about storage volumes attached to MSK broker nodes.

The ARN of the AWS KMS key for encrypting data at rest. If you don't specify a KMS key, MSK creates one for you and uses it.

member.summary: Includes encryption-related information, such as the AWS KMS key used for encrypting data at rest and whether you want MSK to encrypt your data in transit.

member.summary:

member.name: T:Amazon.Kafka.Model.EncryptionInTransit
member.summary: The settings for encrypting data in transit.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.EncryptionInTransit.ClientBroker
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ClientBroker.
Indicates the encryption setting for data in transit between clients and brokers. The following are the possible values.
TLS means that client-broker communication is enabled with TLS only.
TLS_PLAINTEXT means that client-broker communication is enabled for both TLS-encrypted, as well as plaintext data.
PLAINTEXT means that client-broker communication is enabled in plaintext only.
The default value is TLS_PLAINTEXT.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.EncryptionInTransit.InCluster
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InCluster.
When set to true, it indicates that data communication among the broker nodes of the cluster is encrypted. When set to false, the communication happens in plaintext.
The default value is true.

The maximum number of results to return in the response. If there are more results, the response includes a NextToken parameter.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.ListClusterOperationsRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The paginated results marker. When the result of the operation is truncated, the call returns NextToken in the response. To get the next batch, provide this token in your next request.

member.summary: This is the response object from the ListClusterOperations operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.ListClusterOperationsResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If the response of ListClusterOperations is truncated, it returns a NextToken in the response. This Nexttoken should be sent in the subsequent request to ListClusterOperations.

member.name: T:Amazon.Kafka.Model.ListClustersRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListClusters operation. Returns a list of all the MSK clusters in the current Region.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.ListClustersRequest.ClusterNameFilter
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ClusterNameFilter.
Specify a prefix of the name of the clusters that you want to list. The service lists all the clusters whose names start with this prefix.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.ListClustersRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:

The maximum number of results to return in the response. If there are more results, the response includes a NextToken parameter.

The paginated results marker. When the result of the operation is truncated, the call returns NextToken in the response. To get the next batch, provide this token in your next request.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.ListClustersResponse.ClusterInfoList
member.summary:

Information on each of the MSK clusters in the response.

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.ListClustersResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The paginated results marker. When the result of a ListClusters operation is truncated, the call returns NextToken in the response. To get another batch of clusters, provide this token in your next request.

member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.Kafka.Model.UntagResourceRequest.TagKeys
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TagKeys.
Tag keys must be unique for a given cluster. In addition, the following restrictions apply:
Each tag key must be unique. If you add a tag with a key that's already in use, your new tag overwrites the existing key-value pair.
You can't start a tag key with aws: because this prefix is reserved for use by AWS. AWS creates tags that begin with this prefix on your behalf, but you can't edit or delete them.
Tag keys must be between 1 and 128 Unicode characters in length.
Tag keys must consist of the following characters: Unicode letters, digits, white space, and the following special characters: _ . / = + - @.
